attributes.title: Physical Stock Take
attributes.description:
Findings.

  •  A physical stock-take of raw materials and finished product was conducted on 12th April 2025 to review the adequacy and effectiveness of existing stock controls at Nakuru branch.
  • We noted that there were stock items with variations listed and tabulated below:
    • Polybags had a variance of +1,109 Pieces
    • Finished product had a variance of -18 pieces
    • Utto oil had a variance of -0.515 Litres/Kgs while all other materials had negligible variations as shown below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should strengthen the polybag movement controls and separate market polybag damages from production polybag damages before raising goods issue in the system.
attributes.effect: • Variances in stock items, especially when there were weekly stock adjustments, implied weakening of stock controls.

value: • We will maintain the existing controls and check on our polybag controls to minimize the variances.
• The stock was okay and therefore controls to be maintained and improved further.

·       In the prior audit report dated 2nd March 2025 stocks were as seen below:

  • Bread +28.25 pcs
  • Polybags +2,721 pcs.
  • White flour and brown flour had a variance of -2.24 kgs and +8.51 kgs respectively
  • The rest of the stock items had minimal variances
Previous
• Inadequate polybag movement controls.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread  Weight
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A spot check on the weights of bread produced at the Crater branch was done on 11th April 2025 to ascertain if the branch was compliant with the Weights and Measures Act (Sale of Bread Rules) Legal Notice 94 of 1970.
  • We noted instances of non-compliance to the standard weights as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to adherence to the required dough/bread weight standards and weighing procedures.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The presence of underweight loaves implied lapses in adhering to the standard dough weights and failure to weigh bread before packing, however the overall average weight sampled indicated minor non-compliance.

value: • The 600g Barrel underweight were caused by slicing off over-proofed loaves but going forward we will monitor the production flow.

• The manager has been advised to adhere to the production procedures governing bread weights whereby dividing ranges should be strictly followed, baking to be controlled, cooling to be monitored to avoid cases of overcooling and tins in rotation to be planned as per production requirement.

•  In the previous audit report, packed bread underweights were noted as follows; 
    • 400g - 48.7%, 600g Barrel-21.4%, 600 g Naivas White- 77.6%, 600g CTW/BT-76% and 800 CTW-46.7%.
Previous
• Control ineffective.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Bread Damages Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted a review of damages arising from production and market delivery/transit processes for the period 1st March to 10th April 2025 to detect if the damage levels were within the set limits.
  • The findings were as follows:
    • The production damage was 0.207% of the total production which was above the set standard of 0.2% with a cost implication of KES 2,130.77.
    • The market damage was 1.31% of the total sales (inc. of supermarket damages) and 0.56% (exc. of supermarket), which was above the 0.5% allowed limit and had a cost implication of KES 234,457.25 as computed below.
  • We also noted that there was a cumulative of 2,431 damaged loaves from supermarkets that had been posted in the system but not recorded in the branch books. Therefore, the computation below was inclusive of the unrecorded damages noted.
attributes.recommendation:
• Enhance quality controls within the production and bread delivery processes to ensure there are minimal/acceptable levels of both production and market damages.
  • Accurate recording of damages in the book records to be exercised.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The production and market damage levels were above the set limits which implied unbudgeted losses/cost incurred due to excess damages, especially market/supermarket damages.
  • Unrecorded but posted supermarket damages implied poor maintenance of parallel records at the branch.

value: • We have had issues with the ovens that affect the bread quality. We need assistance from KAF/management to get the static ovens or full repair of the deck ovens to minimize the damages from both production and market.

• The market damages were above limit by 0.06 which is minimal variation but quality will be improved to avoid and minimize both market damages and supermarket GRNs/ returns which at the end affect our sales.
• During the prior audit dated 2nd March 2025, it was noted that production damages were 0.23% of the production and market damages stood at 0.58% of the total sales.
Previous

• The production damage levels were well controlled implying good quality bread produced.
  • The market damages exceeded the set damage limits implying inadequate and inefficient controls for controlling supermarkets’ bread rotation that resulted in high expired bread returns.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Mixing Chart Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • We conducted an analysis of both the mixing charts and mixing chart summaries for the period 1st March to 10th April 2025 to determine if the raw materials’ consumption were as per the set BOM and if the set yield and quality standards were achieved for production.
  • The following were noted:
    • Average yield was 191.44 loaves per bag
    • Average production was 73.17 bags equivalent to 75.05% of the set target of 97.50 bags.
    • Utto units consumption to bags of flour ratio was 1:1
    • 416 cases of remixes were observed for the reviewed audit period as detailed in the table below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management should work towards attaining full branch capacity production.
attributes.effect: • The branch had underutilized its production capacity by 24.95%.

value: • We produced based on demand/sales therefore we could not fully utilize our production capacity.

• The production controls to be enforced to avoid overproof leading to remixes.
  • Workers to be encouraged to report on duty early enough and avoid absenteeism for better production target achievement.

•         During the prior audit, the following were noted: 
     

    •        Average yield 191.46 loaves

    •        Average production 73.06 bags

    •        Nil remixes were observed.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A cash count done on 12th April 2025 revealed that there was a negligible variance of KES +38 arising from cents difference during casual workers’ payment.
  •  We also observed that there were 2 pending IOUs dated 9th March (KPLC facilitation for outage fixing) & 10th April worth KES 4,200
attributes.recommendation: • Follow up on clearance of the pending IOU.
attributes.effect:
• Cash controls were adequate and effective.
  • Pending IOU dated 9th March implied non-compliance to the 3-day IOU clearance policy

value:
• We will maintain the controls in place for cash and improve further.
  • To follow up on clearance of IOUs with Operations.

• The cash controls in place to be maintained.
  • Follow up to be done on pending IOU.
• The previous audit report dated 2nd March 2025 indicated a variance of KES 20.75 and pending IOUs worth KES 28,000.
Previous
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Debtors' Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An analysis of the debt balances as at C.O.B 09/04/2025 (Exclusive of Supermarkets) was performed to identify any occurrences of bad debts or unresolved balances by route.
  • We noted that the outstanding debt for customers and schools was KES 805,711.97 .
attributes.recommendation: •  Follow up on pending balances for clearance.
attributes.effect: • Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.
attributes.remediation_plan: • Follow up to be done on pending balances for clearance.

value: • Sales representative is following up on this.

• The sales representative is following up.
    • Sales Rep Comment-Ongeri
    • Some customers clear before next order, schools clear monthly and there are 5 dormant accounts which I am following up on to get letter from customers to allow us to recover from security deposit.
• The previous audit noted that there was an outstanding balance of KES  741,762.46 and three dormant accounts totaling to KES 24,623.22.
Previous
• Debt balances were an indication of long outstanding debts that could potentially become bad debts.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Production Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was done on the efficiency of criteria for labour allocation to the production section for the period 1st March to 10th April 2025.
  •  We noted that the average production efficiency was 4.20 bags per production worker which was below the set standard of 4.5.
  • The results were as detailed below:
attributes.recommendation: •  Branch management to facilitate optimal allocation of employees to the production section.
attributes.effect:
Implication:

  • The branch overallocated 48 workers to the production section with a cost implication of KES 52,156.80 implying an unbudgeted extra cost incurred

value: • The efficiency was affected by oven breakdowns and absenteeism; however, we are in the process of recruiting more workers to prevent/minimize cases of absenteeism noted to improve efficiency.

• Once shift employees are absent and breakdown occurs, the efficiency is affected but with the recruitment of more staff, we are aiming to have employees working few days and have adequate rotation to improve on our efficiency.
• The previous audit report dated 11th February 2025 indicated a production efficiency of 4.10 bags per production worker.
Previous
Controls effective.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • An assessment was conducted on the utilization of packers in the slicing section to determine if optimality was attained based on the set Company standard of 97 crates per packer.
  • We noted that, for the period 1st March to 10th April 2025, the packing efficiency stood at 93.49 crates per packer, which was subpar compared to the set standard as demonstrated below:
attributes.recommendation: • The branch management to work towards optimizing the allocation of packers based on the set standards.
attributes.effect: • The branch did not attain the set packing efficiency implying an excess allocation of 15 packers with a cost implication of KES 13,680.

value: • Efficiency was affected by absenteeism; however, we are in the process of recruiting more workers to prevent/minimize cases of absenteeism noted in order to improve efficiency.
• We will ensure follow-up and proper supervision of packers is enforced for better achievement of efficiency.
• The previous audit report dated 2nd March 2025 indicated a packing efficiency of 86.22 crates per packer.
Previous
Inadequate controls.
Operations/Production Department

attributes.title: Vehicle Fuel Consumption Analysis
attributes.description:
Findings.

  • A review was conducted on the branch vehicles’ fuel consumption vis a vis the set standard consumption rate to determine if there was optimal utilization of fuel for the period 1st March to 10th April 2025.
  • All route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard as detailed in Appendix I(a) & I(b) below except for a few instances which had explanations/reasons as shown in the remarks.

Appendix 1(a)
attributes.recommendation: • Maintain the fuel management controls within the branch.
attributes.effect: • Fuel consumption for vehicles at the branch was well controlled, however, there was room for improvement on existing controls.

value:
• The KDQ 556Z , operations to follow up with KAF/sales personnel
  •  As for the supermarkets route, the vehicle covered extra distance for 2 days when it went to deliver in Kericho 2 route.
• We will maintain the existing controls.

•  During the previous audit dated 2nd March 2025,  It was noted that all route vehicles’ fuel consumptions were within the set standard except for 2 vehicles, Kericho 1 route that consumed more 23 litres fueled to Nairobi for repairs and supermarket route that had faulty speedometer. KDQ 556Z for Molo had excess savings of 68 Litres as well.
Previous
Operations/Production Department
